titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William Hooper Letters, 1867
titlestmt.author: Processed by: Rubenstein Staff; EAD finding aid derived from MARC record using marc2ead_sectionA.xsl

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid derived from MARC record via marc2ead_sectionA.xsl, November 2021

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.abstract: Letters from William Hooper, who with his brothers, J.D. and Thomas C. Hooper, and R.F. Hunt, comprised the faculty of the Wilson Female Seminary, to Maria J. Beattie, a graduate of Edgeworth Seminary, Greensboro, North Carolina, concerning her qualifications for teaching in the Wilson Female Seminary; and a personal letter dealing with a family matter.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.p: William Hooper letters, 1867, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.p: This finding aid was derived from a MARC record using a crosswalk defined in marc2ead_sectionA.xsl. The finding aid was generated as part of a larger project to digitize several thousand small collections housed in Section A, November 2021.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: William Hooper was an instructor at Wilson Female Seminary (Wilson County, North Carolina).

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Letters from William Hooper, who with his brothers, J.D. and Thomas C. Hooper, and R.F. Hunt, comprised the faculty of the Wilson Female Seminary, to Maria J. Beattie, a graduate of Edgeworth Seminary, Greensboro, North Carolina, concerning her qualifications for teaching in the Wilson Female Seminary; and a personal letter dealing with a family matter.
